vitalSign.name: Floodplains
vitalSign.lead: Jennifer Burke, Nathalie Hamel, and Leah Kintner, Puget Sound Partnership
vitalSign.what: A floodplain is the low-lying area adjacent to a river channel or estuarine embayment that can be inundated by flood water or allow channel migration.~P Floodplains are dynamic landscapes that provide irreplaceable ecosystem services including vital habitat and biological processes for the health and survival of Pacific salmon and steelhead, mitigating damage from floods, providing recreational opportunities for the public, and in many cases supporting resource lands such as agriculture.~P In Puget Sound, intact, healthy floodplains:~SL Provide habitat for Endangered Species Act (ESA)-listed salmon, important to generations of Tribes.~B Protect billions of dollars of development and infrastructure by providing flood storage and mitigating flood flows.~B Provide some of Washington State’s most productive agricultural land and public recreational opportunities.~B Provide a variety of other ecosystem and resiliency functions such as water filtration.~EL ~P As population growth and associated development needs continue to modify floodplains, the ability of floodplains to provide ecosystem services is impaired, with potentially adverse consequences to people, property, habitats, and the species they support. ~PThe Floodplains Vital Sign tracks protection, loss, and progress toward recovering the function of floodplains associated with major rivers in Puget Sound.
vitalSign.key-messages: ~SL The total area of floodplains along major rivers is currently estimated at 467,280 acres. Over half of the floodplain area is degraded to some extent, and the degradation ranges from some loss of function to high loss of function.~B Floodplains are important habitat for Puget Sound Chinook salmon.~B More than 100,000 Puget Sound homes and buildings, valued at $28 billion, are located within a floodplain.~B Floodplain communities are now experiencing frequent “100 year floods” every few years, and climate models predict much the same for the future.~B What is the floodplain community doing? To date, over 4,000 acres of floodplain habitat have been restored.~B The effects of climate change on floodplains are complex. Reduced summer low flow is expected to diminish floodplain function, reduce connectivity to portions of the system, increase water temperatures, and impede salmon migration.  Well-functioning floodplain systems located in watersheds with low imperviousness are likely to be more resilient to climate change impacts than compromised systems in urban watersheds.~B The Department of Ecology is working collaboratively with the Puget Sound Partnership to refine the floodplain baseline conditions to more accurately map and quantify current conditions.~EL
